captions.text:
What it do blood? Welcome to Thug
Notes, yo main hookup for classical literature
summary and analysis. This week we keepin it real with
Crime and Punishment by Fyodor Dostoevsky

Now C&P is the story of one of the
baddest white boys in western literature,

mah boy Roskalnikov, or “Rodya,” as he
like to be called.
One day he rolls up to the house of some ol’

crusty pawnbroker hag to slang some of his
bling for that rent money. After this ho does

my boy straight dirty, he goes to the local
pub where he overhears some other hustlas
talkin mess about this old hag.

Man it sure would be cold and righteous if some
badass mutha just went up and glocked that

bitch. Do society a favor, and give her money
to the po’. Naw mean?

So Rodya steps up. Grabs his self
an axe. Rolls up to the pawnbroker’s crib

and BAM, he straight mercs that bitch like
a cold blooded gangsta. Just when he bout

to bounce, her sister rolls in. Now my honky
be knowin you can’t be leavin no witnesses.

Pop! Pop! That bitch goes down and Rodya bails
before the po-lice arrive.

Days pass and mah boy Rodya tries
to shake the funk of murdering someone. News

comes that a detective by the name of Porfiry
Petrovich wanna holla at our boy. Oh snap!

Porfiry Petrovich lays down the gauntlet
and says “Rodya, stop frontin, I know it
was you that killed these bitches.” But Rodya doesn't fall for that trap. He shakes off that playa hata.
Still tortured by that whack ass deed,
Rodya seeks solace in the arms of some nasty trick named Sonya.
Sonya gets all crunk and tells him

that he gotta turn his self in to the po-po
in order for God to forgive him.

So Rodya goes to the middle of the
market and kisses the ground to beg God for

forgiveness. Then he confesses to Porfiry
and is pinched by the 5-O. Only the hard labor

of prison life in Siberia can give our boy
Rodya salvation.

Now if yo bitch ass be paying
attention, you mighta noticed that Rodya’s

article sounds a lot like Nietzche’s
writings on the Ubermensch

You might even say that Dostoevsky’s
conclusion that one must embrace suffering

to achieve redemption is
a big “fu** you” to Nietzche’s postmodern

nihilism. Ya hear me?
Peep this motif, son: the recurring

disjoint between contemplation and experience.
At first, My dawg Rodya thinks he knows what’s

up just cuz it sound all good and righteous
in his head. some
For example,

homeboy think he can ghost a bitch and not
trip. But, on the real, actually killin a
bitch is too much for this pimpjuice to bear.
Yo this is real talk right here:

the Christian symbolism is underlined by the
pagan symbols of the earth. When dat ho Sonya

tells Rodya to confess, she tells him to kiss
the ground- acknowledging the earth as the

baby mama of all men. It’s like this stunna
is making the transition from a cold, hard

ass rationalist in to an red blooded human
being. Ya heard?

You also best be lookin out for
Dostoevsky’s use of duality up in this heezy.

First off, Roskalnikov’s name straight up
means “schism,” which in basic english

means divide. Now what means is that my boy
Rodya be playin both sides of the court whole

bunch of ways: sensibility
and intelligence, self-sacrifice and self

assertion, God-man and man-God, good and evil.
I could go on, playa!

Look, If you ain’t read this sh**,
you need to get yo ass to the public library and get

yoself a copy.
Thanks for tuning in to Thug Notes, blood,
See yo ass next week.

From my perspective Nietzsche is not a nihilist. That nietzsche realized 
the dangers of nihilism but he also understood that man can no longer find 
meaning in god or nation therefore he created the concept of the ubermench. 
The ubermench is something that a human being should strive to become. I 
think that Nietzsche was all like "Yo forget searching for meaning in 
religion or nation instead focus on self realization".

What do you think?﻿

comments.text:
C&P is my all time favorite book... I read it in HS when I was going 
through a lot of family problems and a really dark time... It's more about 
guilt rather than "salvation"... It's almost 900 page book about the main 
character having to live with the guilt of what he's done even though he's 
the only ones that actually knew about his crime... His crime drove him 
crazy to the point of almost committing suicide... It was only through a 
hooker (Sonya) that he confided in (i suppose he felt he was on her level 
or she was better than him) that she kept his secret but encouraged him to 
seek redemption and clear his conscious and let the chips fall where they 
may...﻿

comments.text:
I think Nietzsche would say that Raskolnikov couldn't stand the reality of 
his own actions. He chose to kill that woman (and then accidently killed 
the other one) but he can't stand by his own choices. R. gives himself up 
because somebody tells him about God and salvation, he needs something to 
punish him for what he chose to do but couldn't handle. If anything, 
Nietzsche would have loved this story.﻿
comments.author: Pascal Vézina

comments.author: Splurgendii C

comments.text:
+Martin Krøyer I would also add to the answer to your previous post, that 
Nietzsche's attitude to former values is not negative in the sense that we 
should outright abandon them. Although he does criticize Christianity 
relentlessly and deems it "the curse of humanity", he nevertheless also 
 recognizes it's contributions to culture. Nietzsche simply want so make 
the value of all former values questionable, because humanity has now 
become aware of the fictionality of our previous values. Since we stand at 
the doorstep of nihilism and our values have been rid of their metaphysical 
origin, we must ask "what value do these values have". In this sense, I 
would say that Nietzsche seeks to question, which might lead to negation of 
some values. I would advise you to be careful with your 
hegelian/dialectical analysis and interpretation of Nietzsche so as to 
avoid the danger of making him something he is not, because you may feel 
somewhat uncomfortable with his rejection of Christian ideals, and thus 
wish to see him as a philosopher of dialectical synthesis between the 
Christian ideals and the rejection of these ideals, motivated somewhat by 
the desire to make him "comfortable" by obscuring him or projecting into 
him some modes of thinking that he did not practice. Do not misunderstand 
me. Your strategy is interesting. There may be something there, but 
Nietzsche does to some extent accept the fact that saying "yes" to things 
requires saying "no" as well and this might entail rejection of 
Christianity as well.
comments.author: ikosabre

comments.text:
+Martin Krøyer When it comes to the ubermensch as a dialectical process, 
instead of as a goal in-and-of-itself, I would state that Nietzsche's 
thinking on the matter is not teleological once again. Again and again in 
Nietzsche's writing the idea that humanity is a bridge and not a goal 
in-and-of-itself repeats regularly. The ubermensch is posited as a great 
promise, something still forming and strange, prophetic, a symbol of future 
creative possibilities. In this matter, I believe, the reach of Nietzsche's 
antiteleologicality cannot be overstated. Since the ubermensch is the 
solution to the problem of nihilism, here is a quote I believe higlights 
the dynamic between the two:

"Nihilism then, is the recognition of the long waste of strength, the
agony of the 'in vain', insecurity, the lack of any opportunity to
recover and regain composure - being ashamed in front of oneself, as
if one had deceived oneself all too long. - This meaning could have been
the 'fulfilment' of some highest ethical canon in all events, the moral
world order; or the growth of love and harmony in the intercourse of
beings; or the gradual approximation of a state of universal happiness;
or even the development toward a state of universal annihilation -
any goal at least constitutes some meaning. What all these notions
have in common is that something is to be achieved through the process
- and now one realizes that becoming aims at nothing and achieves
nothing."

- Friedrich Nietzsche, The Will to Power 12A

As Nietzsche noted, humankind is an oddity among the animal kingdom in the 
sense that we occasionally need to be reminded of our need for purpose and 
goal. Everything we do is defined by goal-orientated thinking. However, as 
Nietzsche  noted above, the modern nihilism is based on the realization 
that this way of perception is based on error and fiction and that in 
actuality, the becoming has no goal and achieves nothing. There is only the 
process. The scale of ubermensch's greatness is defined by his ability to 
accept this becoming without aim and exist in it as eternally rejoicing 
Will to Power, as part of Will to Power. He does not negate the world or 
turn into self-renunciation or nihilistic metaphysics. This also involves 
accepting the negative sides of existence and the "underhuman" in us as 
well. I some sense, the ubermensch is not really about attaining some 
future state of transcended cognition, but rather about coming into terms 
with our all too human flaws as well, as part of the aimless becoming 
itself (although in this case I would say taht Nietzsche's writing, once 
again paradoxically, somewhat seems to waver between seeing the ubermensch 
as a new future state of being or as an affirmation of the present 
condition). In any case, I would agree with you in this sense that the 
ubermensch does not necessarily entail the dialectics of 
absolute/anti-absolute, but is rather a mode of being in a becoming without 
final aims and the logic of absolute affirmation/negation (starngely, by 
affirming everything in existence, the ubermensch somewhat transcends the 
typical logic of absolutes).

I would however admit, that my reading of Hegel himself is non-existent and 
I only have the basic understanding of his philosophy, so it may be that I 
do not fully grasp the finer nuances of your hegelian reading strategy, but 
I believe I understood you sufficiently.

As for the question of redeeming Nietzsche, personally I do not consider it 
my "duty" to "redeem" Nietzsche, in sense of making him "moral" in the 
framework of modern morality and returning him to the fold. I am not 
concerned with making him compatible with modern (or previous) morality by 
modifying it according to "moral" standards, as if it's only a matter of 
"correcting" Nietzsche (of course, to some extent, one must do this if one 
wants to apply said philosophy to modernity. It's just a general principle 
for guiding action for me). Nietzsche believed what he believed and that is 
what it is. I rather believe, that Nietzsche must be confronted with an 
attitude of openness and with some insecurity, instead of with an 
preordained goal of making him "politically correct" or with an attitude of 
confronting him simply in order to vaccinate ones already existing 
belief-system against him. Nietzsche should perhaps be considered as a 
great deconstructivist, a bold explorer and questioner, who opens up new 
avenues of knowledge and horizons of questioning, with the goal of shaking 
the foundations of humanity grown rotten and nihilistic, in order to lay a 
foundation for new being and living. By these questions he allows us to 
explore human agency in a new light (for an example, the 
social-historic-genealogical evolution of our frameworks of knowledge and 
understanding, the dynamics between society and the individual, the impact 
of natural physiology and evolution upon human thinking, the new cultural 
ways of self-perception and self-affirmation in the epoch of nihilism etc). 
He is a teacher of new attitudes, pedagogy of reading and style of being, 
while also making contributions on the field of new knowledge of 
self-understanding and insight of human society, morality and culture (his 
writing is highly diverse in this sense). He wishes to cultivate a stronger 
humanity, who does not suffer from the epoch of nihilism to a 
self-destructive end. I very much agree with Keith Ansell-Pearson (in an 
excellent book "Introduction to Nietzsche as Political Thinker" which I 
would recommend to anyone interested in Nietzsche) when he writes about how 
we should confront Nietzsche as the "first perfect nihilist":

 "In coming to terms with his work
we find ourselves forced to ask, and Nietzsche encourages us to
ask, questions such as: was he so clever? Was he so wise? Did he
write such brilliant books? Is he a destiny? The aim of
Nietzsche's thinking is not to create a new religion, but a new
autonomy. What I would like to call 'an ethics of reading' lies
at the centre of his pedagogy. Whenever we ask the question of
Nietzsche's identity - who is Nietzsche? What does he mean for
us? - we are also asking after our own identity. It is in this sense
that the first perfect nihilist can truly instruct and provoke us.
Through an encounter with his philosophy we can come to a
comprehension of the signs - of descent and ascent, of sickness
and health - of our age. In this way is it possible to 'go over'
(iibergehen) Nietzsche, as we must.
In accordance with his deepest thinking, Nietzsche wants his readers to 
receive him beyond good and evil. This does not mean that we are prohibited 
from criticising, or even rejecting,
his ideas. It does mean, however, that a reception of his work
must transcend the level of a simple 'yes' or 'no'. We must
engage his work and confront its challenge, which is nothing less
than the challenge of thought and a challenge to think."
comments.author: ikosabre

comments.text:
+stmayhem1
But wouldn't you agree with me, that even though reality might be 
impossible for us to know, we are able to experience reality? And if you 
can agree with me on this, is it not then at least possible for reality to 
actually be known to us, though unlikely for it to happen?
comments.author: Martin Krøyer

comments.text:
+ikosabre
As you noted, at the very end, that Nietzsche wasn't so much into just 
turning everything upside down than surpassing, going beyond, current 
values. This is for me a very dialectical reading of Nietzsche, the 
synthesis of both the christian values and negation of these. I have to 
admit I haven't read that much of Kaufmans readings of Nietzsche (though I 
do realize they are 101 on the understanding of his philosophy) so maybe, 
in a very naïve way, the übermensch as a dialectical thinker (as you called 
it) could be as this very synthesis, or maybe in Hegels own terms, the 
concrete followed after a double negation.

Now, just to emphasize the importance of this stance, and maybe you will 
agree with me, that the übermensch is not the negation of any absolute or 
any ideal, but that the übermensch only reveals himself in a double 
negation, that is to say, the übermensch is an X, defined, not as a goal to 
obtain, but rather as a dialectical process. For if the übermensch is to 
live up to its potential, he must always define himself as this 'je ne sais 
quoi', a perspective towards absolutism and anti-absolutism. This is of 
course just quickly written down and this really isn't the media for this 
kind of discussion, but if you can follow through which lines I think.

And truly noted, the tension which the übermensch carries with him, is very 
heraclitian, if you remember/know his parable on the bow; harmony 
constituted through chaos and inner turmoil.

(Since Nietzsche saw consciousness as a surface, one might think of Freud 
and the unconscious, the link here is quite visible.)

You can kindda say that Nietzsche threw in a dynamite together with the 
rest of the established philosophy, closed the door and now it is up to us 
to pick up the pieces.
As such, I personally fear for the übermensch in the nietzschean term, as 
history has already shown us what happens when people try to adopt an 
übermensch attitude, but doesn't have the strength to carry it through. 
This is the reason why I personally try to re-read and redeem Nietzsche, 
because he truly got something right, but was misused and misunderstood - 
it is not the (anti)moral framework of Nietzsche which is of primary 
concern, but those who adopt it.

You did make some comments on it, but how do you see a redemption of 
Nietzsche possible? This is not meant as a rejection of the paradoxical 
nature of the übermensch, for humans as such are paradoxical, but rather 
how do we come to terms with a concept that both rejects the absolute 
judeo-christian ideals but rejoices the animal in us, as the new absolute 
(if you can call it that)? I might have lost a bit of track writing this, 
so excuse my supposedly lack of insight and/or clarity, but in all honesty, 
I am trying to read Nietzsche through Hegel, as you might have noted, which 
is my current project and what I tried to formulate.
comments.author: Martin Krøyer

comments.text:
+Martin Krøyer I would agree with your heraclitian reading. As Nietzsche 
wrote (in Twilight of the Idols, if I remember) attitudes towards life in 
general (whether it is worth living or not, for an example) do not say 
anything about the nature of lite "itself" to Nietzsche, but rather of the 
idiosyncrasies and attitudes of the confessor of those attitudes. They 
reveal the inner world of physiological and psychological sensitivity and 
disposition. Thus, Taking into account the heraclitian, antiteleological 
view of becoming, I believe that the attitudes of "obedience" or 
"rebellion" are themselves only sort of psychological fictions, which 
actuate and motivate the inner impulses and drives of living beings. In and 
of themselves they have no absolute goal or meaning, but offer the illusion 
of meaning and striving, driven by Will to Power (as Nietzsche noted, what 
are "motive" and "purpose" other than dribbles on the surface of the sea of 
consciousness, for consciousness, for Nietzsche, is a surface). I do 
believe that the idea of becoming must to some extent surpass a simple 
notion of absolutes. As Nietzsche noted, an intellectual man uses 
convictions as only tools to greater overcoming. On the other hand, as one 
example of his paradoxical nature, Nietzsche did say that his happiness is 
"yea and nay: a straight line: a goal".

As for the ubermensch, I believe that one should best understand Nietzsche, 
as Walter Kaufmann noted, as a "dialectical thinker". What he meant was 
that Nietzsche is not a "black and white-thinker". He considers 
propositions and phenomenon from multiple angles and their potential for 
life and growth. On the other hand, Nietzsche seems to view tyrannical 
impulses and need for control as, as you noted, signs of secret weakness 
(or at least as they manifest in the slave. The same kind of impulses might 
be motivated by fully different motives and forms of thinking in a master). 
The desire for absolutes and strong faith betray an inner uncertainty. On 
the other hand, I believe that Nietzsche understands that such drives, 
reactionary impulses and ressentiments have played a great part in the 
evolution of the human animal and almost constitute the basis of his 
thinking (for good or bad). Egoism and lust for possession and dominino 
have been perhaps the most necessary, life-preserving and life-enhancing 
drives (and often the most hidden drives). In this sense I believe that, 
tragically, Nietzsche notes that the ubermensch or his cultivation may 
require such instincts for dominion (we should also remember that 
Nietzsche's politics do retain their aristocratic aspects from beginning to 
end. Order of Rank and the pathos of distance, which keep the mob in line, 
are necessary for him, whereas we moderns with out democratic concerns 
might consider his thought on ressentiment with the aim of creating an 
emancipated, all-inclusive political community and thus interpret that 
getting rid of ressentiment means the elimination of hierarchies of 
domination, where as Nietzsche may not think so). Of course, the difference 
is that the ubermensch accepts this tension of existence with glee, rather 
than seeking to do away with it with some "moral" or metaphysical 
redemption of the world. He carries his terrible "yea" to every abyss. 

I would also add that one possible problem with your idea of the "noble" 
side of the ubermensch is that that interpretation may own it's 
interpretive logic to the very Judeo-Christian moral framework, which 
Nietzsche seeks to overcome. Our fears of the ubermensch may thus be the 
result of the Christian moral training, which predisposes us to view the 
relativistic consequences of the Death of God. as a great danger. Thus we 
view these consequences as dangers of the ubermensch ideal, even though 
they may spring from our old modes of thinking about morality. Such 
problems may in this sense rather be the problems of the old framework and 
not the new ideal and transvaluation. But once a certain mode of thinking 
is transvalued and overcome, the former problems also disappear or appear 
in a new light. But I admit that this is rather a point on my and may not 
reflect the whole of Nietzsche's attitude. The problem is that you perhaps 
cannot logically presuppose that a problem constituted by the former ways 
of thinking are problems anymore if one considers them from the new 
perspective. This is a problem for us, not Nietzsche himself necessarily. 
The transvaluation of all values presupposes the (perhaps) momentary 
shelving of those ideals.   But Nietzsche did not seek to abolish all 
"enjoyable feelings" nor does his "immoralism" simply mean a reversal of 
all previous values ti their opposites. Nietzsche's "immoralism", as 
Kaufman noted, is rather defined by his criticism of any abslotu and simple 
dichotomy of good and evil.
comments.author: ikosabre

comments.text:
+ikosabre
Btw, I loved the way you read Nietzsches tragic sickness and death in an 
almost aristotelian way, that Nietzsche turned his own life into an 
aristotelian tragedy, great reading!
comments.author: Martin Krøyer

comments.text:
+ikosabre
The nietzschean pantheism is deeply rooted in his philosophy, you might say 
that since Nietzsche wanted us to become Gods ourselves, therein lies the 
pantheism. But, in all honesty, it was something I read in a quick without 
really going into subject matter.

I have a little insight into the antiteleological statement you made, maybe 
you will agree with me: Isn't the Nietzschean attitude towards life not 
heraclitian? If we look at the human attitude towards the living God, we 
might call it 'obedient', which lies close to nietzschean slave morality 
and the more postmodern attitude towards God as a sort of 'rebellion', 
exclaiming 'God is dead' and master morality. Isn't the true nietzschean 
insight that we should neither live in 'obedience' or 'rebellion' but in 
'independence'? That the true nietzschean attitude towards life and truth 
is neither that of being and non-being (nihilism) but of becoming? I really 
do believe that reading Nietzsche in this heraclitian sense is much more 
accurate.

Concerning your machiavellian comment: I do agree with you in the 
paradoxical nature of the übermensch, and one might blame me for trying to 
redeem Nietzsche in an inappropriate way. Yet what I find troubling here is 
the will to suspend the more noble side of the übermensch. For what is the 
übermensch if it is constantly suspended in favor of its own beastiality? 
Then you might turn the übermensch into a Big Other, as a sort of necessity 
to further human progression which is, to me, a true ideological danger. 
You will fall into the lacanian "if there is a god, everything is 
permitted". So you see my concern, that for one to obtain the status of 
übermensch we have to suspend the übermensch alltogether.
comments.author: Martin Krøyer

comments.text:
+stmayhem1  "'Reality as it is' you say? Very confident! Let me tell you 
something. Not one person knows or CAN know 'reality as it is'. Nietzsche 
is open to interpretations, just like any other great philosopher. Anyone's 
interpretation will be their own mental projection, a psychological 
portrait, so to speak."

Interesting that you would make such a claim of epistemic relativism, yet 
retain a worldview which posits absolute meaning, metaphysics and morality 
(and of course you do not seem to ask whether this mode of self-deception 
applies also to human Christian ideals as well or their historical 
emergence. To you of course they are Godly in origin and not in the realm 
of such invention) . But you are of course correct, "reality" is nothing 
without the active interpreter and for the majority of humankind's history 
pays homage to the fact that interpreting into things only what one wishes 
to be true is the norm. 

As for your comment of letting go of one's ego, well in this I agree. It 
truly is hard to surrender it. Thus the priests and theologians have 
invented the most holy, beautiful, self-aggrandizing, magnificent, 
bombastic and awe-inspiring principles in order to make this transaction 
easy and possible. There is no shame in submitting to such an authority. It 
almost becomes a test of character that one does not throw oneself to the 
ground in front of such magnificent power.
comments.author: ikosabre

comments.text:
+ikosabre
'Reality as it is' you say? Very confident! Let me tell you something. Not 
one person knows or CAN know 'reality as it is'. Nietzsche is open to 
interpretations, just like any other great philosopher. Anyone's 
interpretation will be their own mental projection, a psychological 
portrait, so to speak. God an easy way out? It's the hardest way of all, to 
surrender one's Ego, one's Superman.
comments.author: stmayhem1

comments.text:
+Martin Krøyer While majority of your commentary on Nietzsche is solid 
(although I would state that the relationship between the machiavellian 
aspect of the ubermensch and his non-conflictual aspect is much more 
complex. On one hand Nietzsche does believe that the ubermench is not 
motivated by ressentiment or need for control caused by secret impotence, 
but he also seemed to realize that a machiavellian attitude may be 
necessary for the future ubermensch in order to bring about aristocratic 
politics of re-evaluation, since the depression of cultural identity and 
self-image of humanity brought on by Christianity is so severe. As he 
stated in BGE, the bestial, predatory and serpentine aspects of man also 
have their important part in the general economy of life and may be 
necessary if life and man are to be further enhanced), I would not describe 
Nietzsche as a pantheist. He very much makes it clear that to him, the 
universe is an antiteleological, lifeless entity. It has no character on 
it's own. He may speak of the world as Will to Power, but this is only an 
anthropomorphism in order to understand by humanizing. But it's little more 
than a metaphor.
comments.author: ikosabre

comments.text:
+stmayhem1 You can interpret Nietzsche's life is such a cowardly manner, in 
which the personal  tragedy, suffering and inevitable death is proof of the 
erroneous ways of his philosophy (and thus fall into the fallacy of 
thinking that faith must be true because it is comforting and useful, a 
very uncritical and servile attitude), if you wish. Or you can see that 
Nietzsche, in accordance with his tragic worldview and view of himself as a 
tragic philosopher, remained true to himself in the end. He bore the weight 
of his philosophical insights despite their crushing weight and didn't turn 
to faith or God for an easy way to solve his epistemic crisis. He himself 
believed that only the strongest and intellectually upright person could 
face reality as it is (without gods, metaphysical meanings or any 
teleology) without resorting to typical lies and fictions people have 
turned to for thousands of years out of fear and necessity. 

Also, his insanity may have been caused by actual physical ailments, such 
as syphilis, dementia or tumor (on this subject there is much debate). In 
his later works, Nietzsche shows no signs of suffering from some sort of an 
insanity inducing existential crisis brought on about by lack of faith, but 
rather a very cheerful attitude towards life and thankfulness for his life, 
despite the gravity of his insights. Bangs of conscience due to lack of 
faith do not seem to bother him, as he states himself in Ecce Homo.
comments.author: ikosabre

comments.text: +Martin Krøyer A fine exposition, have a +1
comments.author: Pascal Vézina

comments.text:
Nietzsche called Dostoyevsky a 'kinsman' (see Nietzsches letter to Peter 
Gast, march 7., 1887), just to give some perspective on their relation. One 
thing many people, even scholars, don't realize about the übermensch is 
that it is not in his interest to harm or control other people - many tend 
to blend the übermenschs spirit together with a machiavellian attitude. So 
he cannot do anything he wants, if he desires to be an übermensch. If you 
desired power and control over others, then this only reflects that you 
need others to stay in power and therefore have no authentic power. +Pascal 
Vézina is right in saying that Nietzsche wouldn't have liked the crime to 
begin with, because any excessive expression of power, rage or violence is 
a sign of symbolic impotence - and therefore you abandon the idea of the 
übermensch, by feeling it necessary to show power to stay in power.

R. does not take responsibility for his own actions, he should have sought 
out to redeem himself (going to the police is always a good start) instead 
of letting God do it, though I do understand that this must have been a 
horrible situation for him.

+stmayhem1 is right, as far as I can tell, about the guilt trip from R. but 
two things on Nietzsche: God IS dead, not because Nietzsche denied his 
existence by saying 'God is dead' (Nietzsche was a pantheist) instead he 
meant that our society and philosophy simply transgressed him, we killed 
him by outgrowing him, like a kid not believing in Santa Claus anymore. 
Btw, Nietzsche didn't see Gods death as a positive thing. Though I like 
Baudrillards take on Nietzsche much better: 'God is not dead, he is 
hyperreal'.
The second thing is that it was not his philosophy which drow him to 
madness. It was due to a mental collapse he suffered after trying to 
protect a horse - the following years he did become mad, but that is 
because of a brain tumor and not syphilis as the myth says.

Great comments though, have a nice day d(^.^d)
comments.author: Martin Krøyer

comments.text:
Nietzsche's and Raskolnikov's mistake is to identify with the principle of 
God by declaring that God has died, the result being that moral 
responsibility falls now upon one's own shoulders, e.g. man in charge of 
his morals can do anything he wants. However, because in reality God has 
never died, it exists forever as an a priori source of morals; therefore 
Raskolnikov cannot bear the guilt of murder, and Nietzsche goes insane due 
to immense weight of the principle of God embodied in his Ubermensch ideal, 
that Nietzsche himself tried to be. The moral of the story is as follows - 
don't be an ass - your little Ego will never replace God, for real, yo.
comments.author: stmayhem1

comments.text:
You are suggesting that Nietzsche would've say that Rodya acted following 
his desire, acording to his will to power, being the bird of prey over the 
weak, the Ubermensch. He regretted because he could not hold the blame; He 
couldn't transvaluing morality, falling into the herd... In his last days, 
he had been deeply identified with Rodya. He couldn't even act and live 
according to his thought.
comments.author: Oscar Eduardo Alquízar

comments.text:
I think that's kind Dostoevsky's point though. Like as humans we can 
rationalise all we want and make these decisions and even carry them out, 
but ultimately we are limited in our understanding of morality and 
ourselves. We never know how we are going to react to a choice until we 
carry it out, no matter how much we rationalise, which I think renders the 
idea of the "Ubermensch" impossible.
comments.author: Vicki Langridge

comments.text:
Although, after some thought, Nietzsche might have thought the original 
crime wasn't much better than the outcome. Killing an old lady because some 
drunks egged you on is hardly defensible. R. just missed the chance to own 
his actions, however ressentiment-filled and pointless they were.
comments.author: Pascal Vézina

and moral realism of the masses.
